abstract.text: In response to the ongoing global pandemic, progress has been made in understanding the molecular-level host interactions 9 of the new coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 responsible for COVID-19. However, when the virus enters the body it interacts not 10 only with the host but also with the micro-organisms already inhabiting the host. Understanding the virus-host-microbiome 11 interactions can yield additional insights into the biological processes perturbed by viral invasion. With this aim we carry out a 12 functional analysis of previously published RNA sequencing data of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from eight COVID-19 patients, 13 twenty-five community-acquired pneumonia patients, and twenty healthy controls. The resulting microbiome functional profiles 14 and their top differentiating features clearly separate the cohorts. By examining the functional features in connection with their 15 associated metabolic pathways, differentially abundant pathways are indicated, compared to both the community-acquired 16 pneumonia and healthy cohorts. From this analysis, distinguishing signatures in COVID-19 respiratory tract microbiomes are 17 identified, including decreased lipid and glycan metabolism pathways, and increased carbohydrate metabolism pathways. Here 18 we present a framework for comparative functional analysis of microbiomes, the results from which can lead to new hypotheses 19 on the host-microbiome interactions in healthy versus afflicted cohorts. The findings from this analysis call for further research 20 on microbial functions and host-microbiome interactions during SARS-CoV-2 infection. 21 Introduction 22 An impressive number of scientific studies have rapidly been published on the genomics and molecular-level host interactions 23 of the new coronavirus SARS-Cov-2 1 of reported bat origin, 2 responsible for the COVID-19 disease pandemic. Additionally, 24 understanding changes in the microenvironment within the host can yield insights into related biological processes perturbed 25 by the virus. An increase in opportunistic organisms and an enhanced capacity for nucleotide and amino acid biosynthesis 26

and carbohydrate metabolism has been associated with increased SARS-CoV-2 presence in fecal microbiomes. 3 It has been 27 suggested that gut microbiota could contribute to the pathology of the gut-lung axis during The respiratory 28 1 microbiome members during the respiratory virus SARS-CoV-2 infection have also been studied. 1, [5][6][7] Previous studies on 29 the respiratory tract microbiome during other pathogen infections have examined its predictivity of clinical outcomes, and 30 associated potential probiotic interventions. 8-12 31 To better understand the role of the respiratory microbiome in COVID-19, we introduce a functional analysis, as opposed to 32 taxonomic naming, of recently published metatranscriptomes 5 from bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) of COVID-19 patients, 33 healthy subjects, and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) cases. While Shen et al. 5 focused on the SARS-Cov-2 genomes 34 and taxonomic profiling of the microbiomes, here we perform global functional profiling to characterize altered biological 35 processes the respiratory tract microbiomes. Our protein domain focused amino acid matching approach supports the profiling 36 of functions performed by known and potentially unknown organisms yet to be characterized. 13 The robust comparative 37 analysis presented here was designed to highlight consistent differences in COVID-19 patient microbiomes compared to both 38 community-acquired pneumonia and healthy control samples.

Functional profiling framework 41 The overall analysis workflow is depicted in Fig. 1A . The total RNA sequencing reads were first trimmed and filtered, followed 42 by translation and functional classification with PRROMenade 14 against a vast amino acid sequence collection of 21 million 43 bacterial and viral protein domains from the IBM Functional Genomics Platform, 15 annotated with KEGG enzyme codes 44 (EC) from a corresponding functional hierarchy 16 (see Supplementary Fig. S1 for filtering results). Post-processing and robust 45 rank-based RoDEO 17 projection onto a unified scale was performed to make the resulting functional profiles comparable. 46 Microbiome functional profiles cluster by cohort 47

for COVID-19 versus the other cohorts, we extracted 30 top-ranked features from the COVID vs. CAP comparison and from 60 the COVID vs. healthy controls comparison. We then considered the union of the feature sets, resulting in 44 EC features.

When clustering the samples using the top differentiating features, the COVID-19 samples are grouped together and separate 62 from the other cohorts, except for sample 4 (Fig. 2) . While the examined 44 features were selected as those differentiating 63 COVID-19 from CAP and healthy controls, they also separate the healthy control samples from all others; the healthy controls 64 cluster tightly together. The results also demonstrate that the samples do not merely cluster by the total number of input reads or 65 the fraction of functionally annotated microbial reads, since those measures vary within cohorts (Supplementary Fig. S1 ). The 66 CAP patient samples were collected from different hospital sources, prior to the current pandemic, and represent pneumonia 67 cases with various viruses detected in the sequencing data 5 (e.g. enterovirus, influenza virus, rhinovirus), possibly contributing 68 93 suggested. 24 94 Among the pathways higher in COVID-19 are several related to carbohydrate metabolism, e.g. glycolysis/gluconeogenesis 95 (Table 1) . Enhanced microbial capacity for carbohydrate metabolism (glycolysis II from fructose-6-phosphate) has previously 96 been indicated in fecal samples with a signature of high SARS-Cov-2 infectivity, along with decreased abundance of short-chain 97 fatty acid producing bacteria. 3 98 Discussion 99 Analyzing COVID-19 respiratory tract metatranscriptomes from a functional perspective offers an additional view into their 100 differences from healthy controls and from subjects with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The comparative approach 101 taken here aims to mitigate possible experimental variation and resulting biases within individual samples, by focusing on 102 detecting robust and consistent differences in the detected microbial functions. The framework presented here includes 103 read filtering, functional annotation with a protein domain database and enzyme hierachy, feature abundance projection to 104 a comparable scale, and finally metabolic pathway scoring to indicate differentially abundant functionalities in COVID-19 105 microbiomes compared to healthy and CAP samples. As a result, we identified both enzyme code features and metabolic 106 pathways that differentiate COVID-19 respiratory tract microbiomes. The resulting functional profiles distinguish COVID-19 107 samples from others, similarly to the original taxonomy-based analysis of the community members. 5 108

The differentially abundant functions and pathways identified here match findings from previous reports, relating to 109 decreased lipid and glycan metabolism, 21 increased carbohydrate metabolism, 3 and other characteristics of the microbiome 110 linked to The remaining findings can suggest novel host-microbiome interactions to be examined further.
